title-group.article-title: Cardioprotective 22-hydroxylanostane triterpenoids from the fruiting bodies of Phellinus igniarius

sec.p: Cardioprotective 22-hydroxylanostane triterpenoids from the fruiting bodies of Phellinus igniarius
Yu-Ting Li a , Zhen Zhang b , Yunjiang Feng c , Yuanyuan Cheng d , Shuyuan Li b , Can Li e , Li-Wen Tian a, *
a Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of New Drug Screening, School of Pharmaceutical Sciences , Southern Medical University , Guangzhou, 510515, People ’ s Republic of China
b School of Traditional Chinese Medicine, Guangdong Pharmaceutical University, Guangzhou, 510006, People ’ s Republic of China
c Griffith Institute for Drug Discovery, Griffith University, Brisbane, 4111, Australia
d School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Guangzhou University of Chinese Medicine, Guangzhou, 510006, People ’ s Republic of China
e Central Laboratory, Southern Medical University, Guangzhou, 510515, People ’ s Republic of China
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Lanostane triterpenoids
Cardioprotective activity

sec.title: ABSTRACT
sec.p: Seven undescribed 22-hydroxylanostane triterpenoids were isolated from the fruiting bodies of Phellinus igniarius , together with three known sterols. Their structures were assigned by extensive spectroscopic and HRESIMS data analyses. The absolute configurations of C-22 were determined by X-ray crystallography, chemical methods, and spectroscopic data comparison. Phellinol G was a 25,26,27-trinorlanostane triterpenoid glycoside. 22 S /22 R - 25,26,27- Trinorlanosta-8-en-3 β ,22,24-triols with the same side chain as that of phellinol G were stereoselectively synthesized from commercial lanosterol for the first time. The key step involved Sharpless asymmetrical epoxidation. Phellinols A, B, and F showed cardioprotective activity against oxygen-glucose deprivation/reoxygenation injury in H9c2 cells at a concentration of 20 μ M.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The macromycete Phellinus igniarius (L.) Qu´el, ( Hymenochaetaceae ) usually hosts on trunks of conifers or broadleaf trees, and leads to white rot on timbers ( ). The fruiting bodies of P. igniarius , called “Sanghuang” in Chinese, have been historically used as a folk medicine for the treatment of endometrorrhagia in gynecology ( ). In recently years, they have been used as auxiliary antitumor supplements in Asian countries ( ). Previous chemical investigations on the fruiting bodies of P. igniarius have led to the identification of structure interesting styrylpyrones ( ; , ) with anti-oxidative and cytotoxic activities, as well as other phenolic compounds ( , , ) and diterpenoids ( ). Additionally, several sterols and sesquiterpenoids were identified from the cultures of P. igniarius ( ; ; ) with significant antiviral and vascular-relaxing activities.

Cardioprotection refers to reduce the injury from myocardial ischaemia and reperfusion ( ). The current cardioprotection methods mainly include non-pharmacological interventions and pharmaceutical treatments. At present, the clinical used drugs are not ideal, and the discovery of an effective cardioprotective drug that can be given before or at reperfusion is still demanding ( ). As a continuation of our interests in the chemistry and bioactivity of macromycetes ( ), a chemical investigation on the fruiting bodies of P. igniarius led to the isolation of seven previously undescribed 22-hydroxylanstane triterpenoids, phellinols A-G ( 1–7 ), along with three known sterols 8–10 . The absolute configurations of C-22 were determined by X-ray crystallographic analysis, chemical methods, and comparison with the reported spectroscopic data. The cardioprotective activity of compounds 1–10 was evaluated. Herein, we describe the isolation, structure elucidation, and cardioprotective activity of these isolated compounds.

sec.title: 2. Results and discussion
sec.p: The methanolic extract of P. igniarius was subjected to column chromatography over MCI CHP20P, silica gel, Sephadex LH-20, ODS, and high performance liquid chromatography purification to yield seven undescribed 22-hydroxylanostane triterpenoids, phellinols A-G ( 1–7 ), together with three known sterols ( 8–10 ) ( Fig. 1 ). The known compounds were identified as ergosta-7,22-diene-3 β -ol ( 8 ) ( ), ergosta-7,22-diene-3- one ( 9 ) ( ), and phellinignincisterol C ( 10 ) ( ), by comparison of their spectroscopic data with those reported in literatures.
* Corresponding author.
E-mail address: lwtian@smu.edu.cn (L.-W. Tian).

Compound 1 was isolated as a colorless needle. Its molecular formula was determined to be C 30 H 46 O 3 by the positive HRESIMS. The 1 H NMR spectrum of 1 showed the signals of two olefinic protons at δ H 6.77 (d, J = 6.9 Hz, H-7) and 5.28 (d, J = 5.9 Hz, H-11), two oxygenated methines at δ H 3.24 (dd, J = 11.6, 4.2 Hz, H-3) and 3.91 (m, H-22), one secondary methyl at δ H 0.96 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, H 3 -21), and seven tertiary methyls at δ H 0.69 (s, H 3 -18), 0.98 (s, H 3 -19), 1.23 (s, H 3 -26), 1.24 (s, H 3 -27), 1.01 (s, H 3 -28), 0.88 (s, H 3 -29), and 1.07 (s, H 3 -30). The 13 C NMR spectrum of 1 displayed 30 carbons, including a carbonyl carbon at δ C 217.4 (C-15), four olefinic carbons at δ C 124.3 (C-7), 135.1 (C-8), 146.3 (C-9), and 114.6 (C-11), five sp 3 -hybrid methines, two of which at δ C 78.9 (C-3) and 80.4 (C-22) were oxygenated, seven methylenes, eight methyls, and five sp 3 -hybrid quaternary carbons, including an oxygenated at δ C 80.1 (C-25). The above spectroscopic data were close to those of ganodercochlearin A ( ), which possesses a tetrahydrofuran ring in the side chain. The major difference was arisen from the carbonylation of C-15 instead of the hydroxylation of C-24. The chemical shift of H-16 ( δ H 2.54, 2.06) and the HMBC correlations from H 3 -30 and H-17 to C-15 ( Fig. 2 ) revealed a carbonyl group was located at C-15. The up-field shift of C-23 (Δ δ C 2.5 ppm), C-24 (Δ δ C 39.7 ppm), and C-25 (Δ δ C 1.6 ppm) in comparison with those of ganodercochlearin A indicated the disappearance of a hydroxyl substituent on C-24. Further detailed COSY and HMBC correlations analysis ( Fig. 2 ) established the planar structure of 1 , 3-hydroxy-22,25- epoxylanosta-7,9 (11)-dien-15-one. The NOE correlations of H-3/H 3 -28 and H-3/H-5 suggested that H-3 was α - oriented. Though H-22 exhibited obviously NOE interactions with H-16 α and H-16 β , the absolute configuration of C-22 cannot be unambiguously concluded based solely on this information. However, by using single crystal XRD analysis conducted with Cu Kα radiation ( Fig. 3 , CCDC, 2077919), the absolute configuration of C-22 was determined to be R . Thus, the structure of 1 was elucidated as 3 β -hydroxy-22 R ,25-epoxylansta-7,9 (11)-dien-15-one, with a trivial name of phellinol A.

Compound 2 was obtained as white amorphous powder. Its molecular formula C 30 H 50 O 4 was deduced from HRESIMS. Its NMR data ( Table 1 ) were similar to those of 1 , suggesting a lanostane triterpenoid with a tetrahydrofuran ring. The major differences were that the 1 H NMR spectrum of 2 displayed the signals of two additional oxygenated methines at δ H 4.13 (q, J = 3.6 Hz, H-2) and 4.25 (dd, J = 9.8, 5.6 Hz, H-15), instead of two olefinic protons in 1 . The 1 H– 1 H COSY correlations from H-1 to H-3, and from H-15 to H-24, as well as the HMBC correlations of H 2 -1/C-2, H 2 -1/C-3, H-2/C-3, H-2/C-10, and H 3 -30/C-15 revealed the hydroxylations of C-2 and C-15. The position of a fully substituted double bond (Δ 8,9 ) was suggested by the HMBC correlations of H 2 -7/C-8, H 2 -7/C-9, H 2 -11/C-8, H 3 -19/C-9, and H 3 -30/C-8. The small coupling constant (3.6 Hz) between H-2 and H-3 confirmed that they were cis -oriented ( ). The NOE correlations of H-2/H-3, H-2/H-5, H-3/H-5, and H-3/H 3 -28 revealed the α -orientations of H-2 and H-3. The obvious NOE correlation between H-15 and H 3 -18 indicated that H-15 was β -oriented ( Fig. 4 ). The spectroscopic data of the C-20–C-27 sidechain were in good agreement of those of 1 , which suggested that C-22 should be in R form. To provide more justification for this configuration, the acetylated product of 2 ( 2a ), initially obtained by treating 2 with acetic anhydride, was further treated with BBr 3 to yield tetrahydrofuran ring-opening product 2b . The coupling constant of H-22 (dd, J = 9.6, 3.1 Hz) and the proton chemical shifts from H-21 to H- 27 in 2b were similar to those of inonotsuoxodiol A ( ) with the same side chain, supporting a R configuration at C-22. Based on the above evidence, the structure of 2 was assigned as 22 R ,25-epoxylansta-8-en-2 β ,3 β ,15 α -triol and named phellinol B.

Compound 3 possessed a molecular formula of C 30 H 48 O 4 as determined by the positive HRESIMS. The molecule weight of 3 was two mass units less than that of 2 , corresponding to a degree of unsaturation. Comparison of their spectroscopic data revealed that the isolated double bond (Δ 8 ) in 2 was replaced by a conjugated one (Δ 7,8 and Δ 9,11 ) in 3 , as suggested by the chemical shifts of H-7 at δ H 5.86, d ( J = 6.6 Hz) and H-11 at δ H 5.33, d ( J = 4.5 Hz). The position of the conjugated double bond Δ 7,8 and Δ 9,11 was further revealed by 1 H– 1 H COSY and HMBC correlations. The α -orientations of H-2 and H-3, and the β -orientation of H-15 were confirmed by the pertinent NOE correlations. The identical spectroscopic data of the side chain between 2 and 3 suggested that C-22 had an ( R )-configuration. Therefore, the structure of 3 was determined to be 22 R ,25-epoxylansta-7,9 (11)-dien-2 β ,3 β ,15 α -triol, and was given a trivial name phellinol C.

Compound 4 was isolated as white amorphous powder. Its molecular formula was determined to be C 30 H 48 O 7 by the positive HRESIMS. The planar structure was elucidated on the basis of HSQC, COSY and HMBC spectra analysis ( Fig. 2 ). The ABCD-ring of 4 was similar to that of 2 except for the carbonylation of C-7 ( δ C 204.5) and hydroxylation of C-11 [ δ H 4.60, dd ( J = 9.2, 4.5 Hz), H-11; δ C 63.8, C-11]. One significantly deshielded olefinic carbon ( δ C 166.9, C-9) suggested the conjugation of the double bond (Δ 8,9 ) with a carbonyl group. The HMBC correlations from H 2 -6 ( δ H 2.80, 2.56) to C-4 ( δ C 38.1), C-7 ( δ C 204.5), C-8 ( δ C 139.7), and C-10 ( δ C 40.5), and from H-11 to C-8 and C-13 ( δ C 48.8) revealed the locations of additional carbonyl and hydroxyl groups at C-7 and C-11, respectively. The NOE correlation of H-11/H 3 -19 suggested a β -orientation of H-11 ( Fig. 4 ). The relative large coupling constant of H-20/H-22 ( J = 9.2 Hz) and the similar 13 C NMR data of C-20–C-23 with those of inonotsuoxodiol A ( ), being different from those of astraeusins D-F ( ) with same side chain, indicated a R configuration on C-22. The double bond Δ 24,25 adopted an E -configuration as suggested by the NOE correlation between H 2 -24 ( δ H 5.56) and H 2 -26 ( δ H 3.97). On the basis of aforementioned data, phellinol D ( 4 ) was elucidated as 2 β ,3 β ,11 α ,15 α ,22 R ,26-hexahydroxylansta-8,24- dien-7-one.

Compound 5 was assigned a molecular formula of C 30 H 44 O 5 on the basis of HRESIMS. Comparison of the spectroscopic data of 5 and 4 revealed that their ABC-ring was varied. The HMBC correlations from olefinic proton ( δ H 6.58, s, H-1) to C-3 ( δ C 200.2), C-5 ( δ C 46.6), and C-19 ( δ C 25.1), and from H 3 -29 ( δ H 1.16) to C-3 and C-5 indicated the presence of an α , β -unsaturated carbonyl group in A ring. The chemical shifts of C-1 ( δ C 123.7), C-2 ( δ C 143.3), and C-3 ( δ C 200.2) were similar with those of sublateriol A ( ), a C-2 hydroxylated α , β -unsaturated 3-keto lanostane triterpenoid. This information suggested that a hydroxyl group attached to C-2. The 1 H NMR signals at δ H 5.96 (H-7) and 5.58 (H-11), and the 13 C NMR signals at δ C 121.5 (C-7), 140.6 (C-8), 141.2 (C-9), and 117.4 (C-11) were characterized for the presence of a conjugated double bond (Δ 7,8 and Δ). The α -orientation of the hydroxyl group at C-15 was revealed by the NOE correlation of H-15/H 3 -18. The absolute configuration of C-22 was deduced to be R based on the similar spectroscopic data with those of 4 . Accordingly, the structure of 5 was established as 2,15 α ,22 R ,26-tetrahydroxylansta-1,7,9 (11),24-tetraen-3-one, with a trivial name of phellinol E.

The molecular formula of compound 6 was deduced to be C 30 H 46 O 5 from the positive HRESIMS. The spectroscopic data assignable to the BCD-ring exhibited differences from those of 4 . The NMR spectra of 6 showed signals for a conjugated double bond (Δ 7,8 and Δ 9,11 ) at δ H 6.79 (H-7) and 5.40 (H-11), and a carbonyl group at δ C 218.0 (C-15). Further detailed COSY and HMBC correlations analysis revealed the planar structure of 6 as shown in Fig. 1 . The orientations of H-2 and H-3 were determined by the same NOE correlations as those for compounds 2–4 . Consequently, phellinol F ( 6 ) was assigned as 2 β ,3 β ,22 R ,26-tetrahydroxylansta-7,9 (11),24-trien-15- one.

Compound 7 was obtained as white amorphous powder. The molecular formula of 7 was determined to be C 33 H 52 O 9 by the positive HRESIMS. The spectroscopic data of ABCD-ring in 7 was similar to those of 1 except for the down-field shift of C-3 (Δ δ C 9 ppm), possibly due to the glycosidation of C-3. The anomeric proton at δ H 4.15 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, H-1 ′ ), indicative of a β -configuration for glycosidic bond, showed HMBC correlation with C-3 ( δ C 88.1) and NOE correlation with H-3 ( δ H 3.09), suggesting the attachment of a sugar moiety to C-3. Enzymatic hydrolysis of 7 yielded D-glucose, as revealed by HPLC analysis and comparison with corresponding derivatives of standard D/L-glucose. Detailed HSQC, COSY, and HMBC spectra analysis ( Fig. 2 ) revealed a 25,26,27-trinorlanostanoid. The NOE correlations between H-3 ( δ H 3.09) and H-5 ( δ H 1.03) indicated that H-3 was α -oriented ( Fig. 4 ). The absolute configuration of C-22 was proposed to be R based on the biosynthetic consideration. On the basis of the above-mentioned data, the structure of 7 was elucidated as 3- O -β -D-glucopyranosyl-3 β ,22 R ,24- trihydroxy-25,26,27-trinorlanosta- 7,9 (11)-dien-15-one, and was given a trivial name phellinol G.

To validate the absolute configuration of C- 22 in 7 , two 22-hydroxy-25,26,27- trinorlanostane triterpenoids epimerized at C-22 were synthesized from the commercial lanosterol ( 7a ). The lanosterol was initially acetylated. Then the double bond Δ 24, 25 in 7b was epoxided by mCPBA, followed by oxidative cleavage with H 5 IO 6 . The yielded product 7d was dehydrogenated by selenium dioxide to afford an α , β -unsaturated aldehyde. Subsequently, reduction of 7e with NaBH 4 gave an allyl alcohol in the side chain of 7f , which was subjected to Sharpless asymmetric epoxidation and Red-Al reduction to yield 25,26,27-trinorlanosta-8-en-3 β ,22 S ,24-triol ( 7i ) and 25,26,27-trinorlanosta-8-en-3 β ,22 R ,24-triol ( 7j ), respectively. In the end, the spectroscopic data of 7i and 7j showed no distinguishable difference, due to the substitution on C-23 was not bulky enough to form the predominant conformation (Fig. 76S). To the best of our knowledge, it was the first time to stereoselectively hydroxylate C-22 for lanostane triterpenoids, through 22 R - and 22 S - hydroxylanostanoids were synthesized ( ; ).

Compounds 1–10 were evaluated for their cardioprotective activity against oxygen-glucose deprivation/reoxygenation (OGD/R) injury in H9c2 cells. Among them, compounds 1 , 2 , and 6 increased the cell viability by 11.6%, 14.04%, and 9.65%, respectively, comparable to that of positive control diazoxide (12.74%) at a concentration of 60 μ M, while compounds 3 , 5 , and 7–10 showed pro-apoptotic effect toward H9c2 cells.

sec.title: 3. Conclusion
sec.p: Seven previously undescribed 22-hydroxylanostane triterpenoids, phellinols A-G ( 1–7 ), were isolated from the fruiting bodies of P. igniarius . 22 S /22 R -25,26,27- Trinorlanosta-8-en-3 β ,22,24-triols ( 7i and 7j ) with the same side chain as that of 7 were stereoselectively synthesized from commercial lanosterol for the first time. Compounds 1 , 2 , and 6 showed cardioprotective activity against oxygen-glucose deprivation/reoxygenation injury in H9c2 cells at a concentration of 20 μM .

sec.title: 4.1. General experimental procedures
sec.p: Optical rotations were measured on a PerkinElmer 341 polarimeter. UV spectra were recorded on a N5000 UV–Vis spectrophotometer (YoKe). IR was performed on a Shimadzu Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. NMR spectra were acquired on an AV-400 or AV-600 NMR spectrometer (Bruker). HRESIMS data were obtained by a maXis Quadrupole time-of-flight mass spectrometer (Bruker). The crystallographic data were acquired on a Gemini S Ultra CCD diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα radiation and a graphite monochromator. Semipreparative HPLC purifications were performed on a shimadzu LC-20A liquid chromatography system with a Thermo hypersil C18 column (250 × 9.6 mm i. d.). Column Chromatography (CC) was performed using silica gel (200–300 mesh, Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Ltd.). MCI CHP20P (Mitsubishi), Sephadex LH-20 (GE Healthcare), or ODS (40–63 μ m, Merck).

sec.title: 4.2. Fungal material
sec.p: Fruiting bodies of Phellinus igniarius (L.) Qu´el ( Hymenochaetaceae ) were purchased from Bozhou TCM market, Anhui Province , China , in July 2016 . They were identified as by Dr. B. Feng , from Kunming Institute of Botany , Chinese Academy of Sciences. A voucher specimen of this material (NO. SMU-NPC-201606 ) was deposited in Natural Product Chemistry Lab , School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Southern Medical University, Guangzhou, China .

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p: Air-dried and powdered fruiting bodies of P. igniarus ( 8.7 kg ) were reflux extracted with MeOH (3 × 20 L, each 2 h), and concentrated to yield the crude extract ( 510 g ). The crude extract was then suspended in water and extracted with ethyl acetate (EtOAc) and n-BuOH sequentially. The EtOAc partition ( 324.4 g ) was fractionated by MCI CHP20P (MeOH–H 2 O, 1:9–1:0) to yield a non-polar fraction ( 96.9 g ), which was later separated by silica gel ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH, 50:1–8:2) to obtain two fractions, 1 and 2. Fraction 1 ( 40.2 g ) was subjected to silica gel (petroleum ether-EtOAc, 50:1–9:1) CC to yield three sub-fractions 1.1–1.3. Sub-fraction 1.1 ( 8.3 g ) was purified by silica gel (petroleum ether-EtOAc, 40:1–9:1) to yield 8 ( 35 mg ) and 9 ( 56 mg ). Sub-fraction 1.2 ( 2 g ) was chromatographed over silica gel ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH, 20:1–8:2), Sephadex LH-20 ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH, 1:1), ODS (MeOH–H 2 O, 8:2–1:0) and HPLC purifications ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O, 3:7–4:6) to afford 7 ( 2 mg ) and 10 ( 3 mg ). Fraction 2 ( 38.6 g ) was separated by Sephadex LH-20 ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH, 1:1) to yield three sub-fractions 2.1–2.3. Sub-fraction 2.2 ( 6.9 g ) was purified by silica gel (petroleum ether-EtOAc, 50:1–0:1), ODS (MeOH/H 2 O, 3:7–1:0) and HPLC purifications ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O, 5:5–6:4) to afford 1 ( 2 mg ), 2 ( 5 mg ), and 3 ( 9 mg ). Sub-fraction 2.3 ( 5.5 g ) was separated over silica gel (petroleum ether-EtOAc, 50:1–0:1), ODS (MeOH/H 2 O, 3:7–1:0) and HPLC purifications ( CH 3 CN–H 2 O, 4:6–5:5) to afford 4 ( 7 mg ), 5 ( 2 mg ), and 6 ( 2 mg ).

sec.title: 4.3.1. Phellinol A (1)
sec.p: Colorless needles; melting point 261–262 ◦ C; [α]25D + 204 (c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 242 (3.94) nm; IR u max 3348, 2962, 2835, 1730, 1435, 1379, 1022 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data, see Tables 1 and 3 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 455.3519 [M + H] + (calcd for C 30 H 47 O 3 , 455.3520).

sec.title: 4.3.2. Crystal data of 1
sec.p: C 30 H 46 O 3 , M = 454.67, monoclinic, space group was P 21 , a = 9.8895 (3) Å, b = 11.7364 (3) Å, c = 11.9982 (4) Å, β = 112.506 (4) ◦ , V = 1286.54 (8) Å 3 , Z = 2, T = 100.0 (3) K, μ(Cu K α ) = 0.566 mm 1 , D calcd = 1.174 g /cm 3 , 10,484 reflections measured (7.976 ◦ ≤ 2Θ ≤ 147.89 ◦ ), 4992 unique ( R int = 0.0321, Rsigma = 0.0286) which were used in all calculations. The final R 1 was 0.0419 (I > 2σ(I)) and wR 2 was 0.1153 (all data). The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.022. The absolute configuration was determined by the Flack parameter = 0.06 (9). The crystal structure of 1 reported here is deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (deposition number: CCDC, 2077919). Copies of these data can be obtained free of charge via the Internet at www.ccdc.cam.ac. uk/conts/retrieving.html (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK ; fax (+44) 1223 336,033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

sec.title: 4.3.3. Phellinol B (2)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25D + 100 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 256 (3.24) nm; IR u max 3749, 1521, 1506, 1031 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data, see Tables 1 and 3 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 475.3788 [M + H] + (calcd for C 30 H 51 O 4 , 475.3782).
a Measured in methanol- d .
4 b Measured in CDCl.
3 c Measured in DMSO‑ d .

sec.title: 4.3.4. Phellinol C (3)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25D + 204 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 244 (4.27) nm; IR u max 3334, 2943, 2833, 1506, 1456, 1020 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data, see Tables 1 and 3 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 473.3631 [M + H] + (calcd for C 30 H 49 O 4 , 473.3625).

sec.title: 4.3.5. Phellinol D (4)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25D + 186 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ): 203 (4.42) nm; IR u max 3375, 2924, 2852, 1670, 1386, 1020 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 521.3471 [M + H] + (calcd for C 30 H 49 O 7 , 521.3473).

sec.title: 4.3.6. Phellinol E (5)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25D + 158 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ): 243 (4.17) nm; IR u max 3334, 2947, 2835, 1683, 1456, 1020 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 485.3249 [M + H] + (calcd for C 30 H 45 O 5 , 485.3262).
a Measured in CDCl.
3 b Measured in methanol- d .
4 c Measured in DMSO‑ d 6

sec.title: 4.3.7. Phellinol F (6)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25D + 75 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ): 242 (3.96) nm; IR u max 3330, 2947, 2835, 1670, 1473, 1024 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 487.3414 [M + H] + (calcd for C 30 H 47 O 5 , 487.3418).

sec.title: 4.3.8. Phellinol G (7)
sec.p: White amorphous powder; [ α ]25D + 504 ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ): 242 (4.18) nm; IR u max 3330, 2918, 2848, 1647, 1506, 1049 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR spectroscopic data, see Tables 2 and 3 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 593.3685 [M + H] + (calcd for C 33 H 53 O 9 , 593.3684).

sec.title: 4.4. Enzymatic hydrolysis of 7 and absolute configuration determination of sugar moiety
sec.p: A solution of 7 ( 1 mg ) in H 2 O (2 mL) was hydrolyzed with snailase ( 6 mg , Shanghai Sangon Biotech Co. Ltd.) at 37 ◦ C for 12 h. The reaction mixture was extracted with CH 2 Cl 2 (3 × 2 mL). The aqueous phase of the hydrolysate of 7 was separated by dialysis bag (Molecule weight cutoff value is 3000) and concentrated to yield sugar residue. The absolute configuration of the glucose was further determined according to the previously reported method ( ). Briefly, to a solution of sugar residue in anhydrous pyridine (2 mL) was added L-cysteine methyl ester hydrochloride ( 1 mg ), and heated at 60 ◦ C for 1 h. The mixture was then added with isothiocyanate (2 μ L) and kept heating for another 1 h. The reaction mixture was analyzed by reversed-phase HPLC, and the derivative of sugar was identified by comparison of the retention time with those of stand D/L-glucose (Sigma-Aldrich, Germany ) treated by the same way as described above.

sec.title: 4.5. Cardioprotective assay
sec.p: Rat cardiomyocyte H9c2 cells were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (ATCC). The H9c2 cells were cultured in Dulbecco’ s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM, Gibco) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, Gibco) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin (Gibco) at 37 ◦ C, 5% CO 2 . The H9c2 cells were subsequently subjected to oxygen-glucose deprivation condition for 6 h, in which cells were put into a chamber saturated with 95% N 2 and 5% CO 2 after medium was washed by PBS and replaced with DMEM without glucose and FBS. The cells were then treated with indicated drugs during the period of reperfusion for another 6 h. Diazoxide was used as positive control. The cell viability was measured by MTT assay ( ).
Declaration of competing interest
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.p: This work was financially supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China [Grant number 81703381] and Guangdong Basic and Applied Basic Research Foundation [Grant number 2020A1515011027].

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112907.
